comments.comment_body:
Interesting how this article isn't about what's best for the people of the USA, rather how to get "our people" i.e. Democrats, elected almost regardless of what policies they support.

More evidence that the divide in the USA is less about differences of opinion in how to run the country but more about "are you one of us or one of them?"

Very sad and potentially very dangerous.  Not as dissimilar  from a Sunni/Shia or a Catholic/Protestant divide as people might think.

The problem with "anyone but Bernie," columns like this, is that they ignore many obvious facts and replace them with unproven suppositions.  First, you assume that what the GOP is offering is a reasonable and acceptable alternative. If that makes sense to you, it means you are one of the millions of Americans who have decided it's okay to flush our democratic republic down the toilet, as long your 401k remains intact.  It also implies that this current economic boom will continue unabated for eternity, that Obama had nothing to do with it, and that it's all happening because Trump is a very stable genius. You make the assumption that we can continue stripping away even the most basic environmental protections and be perfectly okay, as the waters rise to flood our cities and towns.  You make horrific moral compromises, like saying it's okay for our government to put children in cages and greatly expand the private prison system in order to do so.  You make the assumption that America can survive while abandoning our most deeply held principles, intentionally promoting lies, and abandoning even the semblance of fairness in our society. You make the assumption that everyone out there has a nice, fat 401k.  You assume there are other promising candidates like Bernie, who can bring massive followings to the race when there aren't.  You assume Biden is a solid candidate when he's just weak.  You assume there's a solid, moderate candidate to replace Bernie with when there isn't.

Brooks is correct in assessing the formidable strengths of Trump and his party and the inconsequential impeachment farce.
However this piece continues the familiar Establishment cheer-leading for late-stage capitalism despite the evidence of its savage, rigged effects.
Quoting the obscure fantasist Benjamin Friedman is more of Brooks's cherry picking facts and opinions from shaky or shady sources. If prosperity raises moral largess how come the plutocracy squeals like pigs when there is mention of a "wealth tax"?  The needed tax correction is not a new tax, but simply a winding back of the enormous tax reductions going back to Reagan and his successors. 
And Brooks is silent on the opioid epidemic, the war on Medicaid, reduced longevity, student debt, failing infrastructure and endless war.  Our best hope is transformation. Go Bernie.

The Gallup Poll data Mr. Brooks cites doesn't not back up his statement that more Americans identify as Republicans than Democrats. An editor may want to check that link in the story to that Gallup data.
Brooks needs to provide a source before I cry fake news: median wages aren’t rising.

Why do the democrats have to clean up the mess of a giant deficit and restore morality?  The shooting in El Paso was just designated a hate crime.  White supremacy disguised as nationalist on the rise and fomenting race hatred.  Stop looking at the stock market as the ultimate gauge in where are.   We've sold out our values that were once worth something, for tax cuts for the rich and corporations that pay none.  The party of Lincoln is now an empty corrupt party who worships a cult leader and is scared of a tweet.

Trump comparison to Hitler:

Violates or arbitrarily withdraws from international agreements - Hitler’s unilateral withdrawal from Treaty of Versailles

Propaganda on social media - Hitler propaganda movie Triumph of the Will

Fascination with military parades - Hitler had military parades at every opportunity 

Racists white tendencies (fake Jewish support) - Hitler had The Final Solution and Aryan fascination 

Make America Great Again - Hitler: make Germany great again

Race baiting rallies, blaming immigrants for all of America’s woes - Hitler had rallies at every opportunity claiming Aryan superiority and promoting racism

Obsessed with loyalty and adulation (fires people who are disloyal) - Hitler assassinated disloyal members of his party (Sippenhaft)

Supports Neo-Nazis - Hitler: the first Nazi

Surrounds himself and supports thugs - Hitler created the SS

Writes “The Art of the Deal” - Hitler: Mein Kampf on the “Jewish Peril”

Both lied without any consequences. 

If you don’t learn from history, you are destined to repeat it!

David Brooks here wisely appraises the current mood of Americans. The Trump team united confronts with a pugilistic stance the opposing Democratic coalitions, who as a team don't seem ready for prime time. 

Unfortunately, the Trump team has worked the economy well, even if to do so it runs huge deficits and dangerously deregulates. The Democrats may aptly criticize, but nothing seems to succeed like success. America has arrived at prosperity. Trump bets that principle will be overlooked in exchange for the goods on the table today.

Brooks suggest that to effectively counter the Trump team united, a counter aim must be advanced by the Democrats. To run against the unethical, corrupt, morally opportunistic, divisive and re-polarizing, arrogant behavior of Trump: it might be enough. But compared to the economy, such issues might appear as merely rearranging the frosting. The cake, it's baked by Trump.

Michael Bloomberg, however, might more effectively take the Democratic case to the public. A good bet is that he can talk business to the American voter better than Trump. His bright demeanor alone will contest Trump the boor and philistine, the slick reality-tv guy.

Plus his can-do charm might appeal to Americans taken with Trump, the heavy-handed champion of twentieth-century America. Bloomberg might usher in a genuine American renaissance, one even many Trump supporters would prefer.

Trump will finally implode in the next several months. He is almost drunk on bitterness, vindictiveness, and feelings of self-righteousness. His compulsion for self justification will lead him to do and say things that will be indefensible. And everyone carries a phone these days with a recording function. It is only a matter of time till he sinks himself.

At least that is what I keep telling myself, as I refuse to believe he will not ever face accountability.

Here is the great irony:

In 2008, the economy was a garbage fire and we voted in Obama to reshape American society to help 'Main St instead of Wall St' through infrastructure and stimulus and whatever other plans Obama used to talk about.

But then the Republicans started obsessing over the 'deficit.' "Oh, we can't do anything to help the American people because we need austerity in the face of widespread suffering, we need to - in the middle of economic collapse - focus on fixing the deficit."

Now - due to some fairly risky and mostly artificial economic moves by the Fed (QE, low interest, tax cuts, environmental destruction) - we have a strong economy. We also have a ballooning deficit, which just shows that the Republicans rhetoric was completely hollow.

Well, what better time to focus on reshaping American society than now? When we have the resources to actually do it?

So we tax the rich, we tax corporations, we provide people with no-cost healthcare, we let people get educated for free so they aren't saddled with debt, and pass a sweeping green new deal.

Or we wait until the next economic collapse and then start the cycle all over again.
Representative democracy didn’t used to scare Democrats. Please don’t worry. Just because Sanders is president, you can still be rich, while we save the environment and give everyone healthcare.

I don't know?  It seems to me that the case for Trump  -- at least as Mr. Brooks sees the situation -- is the same one made for Mussollini.  Trump argues that he makes the trains run on time, and in the end that's all that matters.  The corruption, the human rights abuses, the dismissal of the rule of law, the nods to the White Supremacist movement along with his consistent and obvious use of the Big Lie technique; all of that bows to the economy.   And if an American election can truly be won on that basis, then the fight for American democracy is already lost.

Afraid he is right. And perhaps Democrats should relax. The next president is going to face an economic crises for certain amid a crises on national indebtedness and an aging population. Let Trump take the dump. 
Despite his nastiness to so many vulnerable people, he is not doing that much harm, at least not too much that can't be undone four years from now. His international policy, chaotic and selfserving, is not undoing much that shouldn't be. We no longer need the cold war hegemony in a world of minor fractionalism. Let him succeed at ending our longest wars. On that there is a unity, mostly based in indifference, that will soon fall apart once it is done.
Undoing his supreme court and reversing his nationalist sins will require a much stronger party than can emerge in a 2020 hair splitter. Sometimes people have to smell their armpits before they see the need for a change of clothes.

I disagree with Mr. Brooks often, and here is no different.  But in an attempt to be productive, I will merely state that the SOTU was not anything like "Morning in America."  Instead, it seemed more like numerous lies, distortions and manipulated statistics, framed within an Oprah-style giveaway show.  Reality TV yet again!

Your last two paragraphs confirm why Buttigieg should be the nominee.  His smarts, eloquence, and practical solutions, let alone is demeanor, would be an amazing contrast to Trump on the debate stage.  One for the ages which would clearly show all that is wrong with Trump and the damage he's done.

I think Democrats will focus on the absolute worse item because either some app told them to do it, or some incompetent campaign director told them it's the right course to follow. It's going to be a path of self destruction. I see Trump for another 4 years. People vote with their pocket books. Sorry.

Trump was NOT politically successful this week. His debased self and the spineless republicans were exposed to voters. Democrats managed to show reality of what Trump is to the electorate.  The voters will reveal in November who was politically successful.

This column convinces me that Bloomberg is not only the best candidate to defeat Trump, but the candidate with the best message—he understands capitalism.

But let’s stop calling it capitalism.  The form of economics where the US (and the world) has flourished is best described, following Deirdre McCloskey, as commercially tested innovation.  Bloomberg knows this well.  Economic history has not been about the accumulation of capital.  We’ve always had “the rich,” nor are the rich the enemy of the non-rich.  Envy is envy, disguising it as class warfare doesn’t change that.

Sorry, Mr. Sanders (and even Ms. warren, if less so), but there is no democratic socialist utopia.  It’s a bad dream—based on bad history.  Both the left and the right are wrong.  Bloomberg is the only candidate, right or left, who appears to know that.

But, gee, maybe he’s too short for a TV age.......so think the political strategists, condescending as they are to all us ordinary folk.

"The unemployment rate is the lowest in decades. Wages are rising. The typical family income is higher than it has ever been."

Hmm. Pretty cynical. I'll leave it to someonelse to summarize all the awful things's he's said and done since elected - Charlottesville remarks being the most egregious which were followed by antisemetic murders. As a Commander in Chief who often ignores the advice of the military and his own intelligence agencies he has the potential to make a serious mistake that could take many lives. 

Of course he'll win again. His supporters love him no matter what he does or says. And Republican pols are in his pocket. How can he not win?

The a Democrats should run on the following slogan:

“We can sustain our strong economy and make it fair for all Americans today and the future without Donald Trump......but we can’t keep our Democracy with him.

Just a reminder that Mr. Brooks is worth nearly 16 MILLION dollars and should inform his readers that he has an inherent conflict of interest in his endless railing against Bernie Sanders, as Mr. Brooks has millions tied up in the stock market

In 2016, Trump ran on Middle America identity politics.

Identity Politics
Political Correctness
Pro-life

These are all marketing terms from the right wing branding machine. They have a way of sticking a simple label on complex issues and then having that label be used in the general language. Don't play their game. When you use their marketing they win even when you disagree.

Equal before the law.
Civility and respect.
Control of women.

David claims: “Democrats, by contrast, have congregated around the message that capitalism is fundamentally broken and that the economy is bad.”

Talk about missing the point! Democrats very definitely do neither. In terms of Capitalism, the Dem position is summarized by the title of Robert Reich’s book “Saving Capitalism for the many, not the few”. The argument, of course, is that greed is not good. In terms of the economy, Dems do not take the view that it is bad, but that it is not well structured. 

David finds Bernie and Warren too much on point, and he is squirming.

I am no Bernie fan — but no matter who the Democratic nominee is — I will make calls, knock on doors and get out every vote I can ....

Honestly, if Bernie supporters are unwilling to support Bloomberg/Buttigieg/or Biden should they win the nomination, then as a country I am afraid we do deserve four more years of Trump.

" ... it looks like the Democratic primary battle is going to go on for a while."

David, it was always going to go on until Super Tuesday.  How the party fares depends on how quickly the left-behind bow out and how quickly those in the lead coalesce around common issues.

Unfortunately the pain of the economy is seen at the local level in terms of housing costs. Democrats are often SQUARELY responsible for the fact that in most places with jobs, you can't afford a house, because they are the champions of development restrictions. 
So yeah, people are employed, wages are going up, stocks are up.  None of this is courtesy of Trump or any politician.  But your rent just went up 10% or buying a home is a distant dream. Or your kids daycare charges what Harvard does. A whole lot of that is because of your local dems. 
I think we'd be better off with conservative local leadership and liberal national leadership.
But honestly, at this point, I can't say any democratic candidate is inspiring me to bother to vote. They have some good ideas, but lack the will to figure out how to pay for it without charging the middle class. If they mess up things nationally like their cohorts have locally, count me out.
Also, Trump is terrible. I've never seen a man and his followers so full of hate and anger. So I have two terrible choices, fiscal irresponsibility or a leadership tinged with hate.

Establishment Democrats and the #NeverTrumpers on the Left and right will not listen to Mr Brooks. They hate President Trump and no appeal to reality is going to change that. Speaker Pelosi tearing up his speech was a perfect illustration of that attitude.

"Confidence in the economy is higher now than at any moment since the Clinton administration."   And that is the tragedy of america.  All you can think about is money.  There are terrible, damaging things being done to citizens, to the environment, to the rule of law, to relationships with other countries, but as long as you have money, you're OK?   If that is true you deserve 4 more years.

Mr. Brooks, 

Where is your lecture to the Republican Party who actually did vote for Trump when he unwittingly won the primary with his platform of prejudice, division, lies, and misogyny? 

Where is your condemnation for the "suburban" voter you seem to believe would again vote for Trump, even though he has proven to be far more dangerous than ever anticipated? 

Your contempt for Senator Sanders and his supporters, repeatedly misrepresenting a large, diverse, committed coalition with the smear of "bernie bros", then blaming that group for Trump's election and feared re-election entirely misses the point. 

If Trump is re-elected it will be that with clear view of his reactionary foreign policy, outrageous camaraderie with authoritarian despots, insane deregulation, punitive nature towards anyone who dare notice the emporer has no clothes (nor any sense of truth, right or wrong) (and I could go on and on), that in clear light of this many Americans would prefer THAT. PERIOD. 

It is obscene to handwring about Bernie and his supporters who want to provide a stronger safety net so the poor suffer less, the sick suffer less, our children suffer less- not out of selfishness but out of compassion.  We are not what is wrong with this country.  We could easily be mistaken as weavers.

For all those who have pondered the question of how it is that nations fall under the “spell” of dictators you have your answer unfolding before your eyes:  the disarray of the opposition and (here) the cowardice of the members of the party in power — aided and abetted by the monied classes.

Most of us don't need or want a revolution,  and that's what's wrong with the Progressive movement. It's time for the group to change their name, join the Socialist Party and leave the Democrats to work things out.  Let's fix what's broken and save what's working. United, we stand; divided, we'll fall. It will be just like the last election.

As one senator said - most senators privately were in favor of impeaching POTUS. I am sure privately they are also rooting for his defeat in November. It is only so much nonsense and drama a sane human can take. And for the "old" and long languishing GOPs including Moscow  Mitch ,it is deleterious to their future mental well being. Democrats now must become passionate and loud. Voters do not hear or register half the things the candidates say unless it is told repeatedly in a dramatic,passionate and loud way. Remember Obama? So Bernie ,take your stand and make it more dramatic and attractive ,even bordering on histrionic and fear mongering. People would like that. Mumbling and monotonous will not work.

Why is it the "people" always,and the media, talk about the extremes of the left but never ,ever the extremes of the right-wing-nuts? Why does the conversation never call tax cuts extreme? Why are destructive policies concerning labor,environment, ,wages,corporate influence never ever called extreme? Why isn't the general apathy and ignorance of citizens ever called extreme? We have a studious and nuanced slate of people in the Democratic mix and they are being labeled extreme.

History would agree, I suppose, that now is the time to "run a values campaign, one that champions policies to make America more socially mobile, caring and interdependent;" however, those who control the government (Republicans) and their supporters do not believe in socially mobile, caring and interdependent values because that empowers Black, Brown, Queer, Asian populations, and women. These groups are antithetical to the Republican, white, male, evangelical minority.

I have just one thought since yesterday.  After forcing myself to listen to Trump's vindictive speech Thursday, I wouldn't put it past him to be plotting (yes, "plotting") with Bill Barr to find some reason to lock up Adam Schiff and Nancy Pelosi.  

Now Trump is unleashed to seek retribution on anyone he feels have wronged him.

This is what is on the homepage of the digital New York Times as I type:
1. "U.S. Added 225,000 Jobs in January; Unemployment at 3.6%"
2. "Black Workers’ Wages Are Finally Rising"
>>>>That's all he needs.
This is what anyone whose been an adult in the USA for at least 20 years thinks:
1. Is there corruption and dirtiness in politics? Of course.
2. Is there lying in politics? Of course.
3. Do I really care about civility? No, not really.  It's a nice-to-have, but the world is filled with conflict and nastiness and sometimes that's necessary to survive.
4. Can I feed my family and put a roof over our heads? It's that last question that is most important because it's the one with direct impact on survival. To any experienced adult, that's all that really really matters - gun rights, abortion, civil rights, climate change, and even health care to the healthy - these are abstractions and compromisable policy positions. Having a job so you can live and eat are not compromisable. And that leads to an essential political truism: If a sitting president is seeking re-election in a good economy, the only person who can unseat him/her is themselves.  So, can Trump be beaten? Yes, but it will not be easy when what really matters to people is their ability to survive and that is going well for the most part for many people. The people who are having a difficult time, such as Gen Z, they need to vote in droves to defeat him.
One small point: Ronald Reagan was not a "generous person" to all Americans.
Still waiting for an actual Democratic candidate to enter the race.

I don’t understand why more isn’t being said about our outrageous debt!  I’m no economic guru but I know enough to realize if you have a huge debt outstanding, ( say like trillions of dollars) you are not in good shape economically. 
Hello!

Yes- it is appalling that Bernie Bros would make a Nader, HRC redux and keep this malignant man in office. But No- it is not really an election turn out fizz to speak of a moral renewal.
We need to cite true pragmatism, different self-interest than the Dow.
We must be better educated, infrastructure must be upgraded or we sink into the sludge of other banana republics or Putin's Russia- a failed shabby remnant of a successful nation.
Paranoid xenophobia, evangelical dismantling of democracy and the privatization of public interests and decimation of competence in the agencies that protect our civilized society (national resources, federal oversights, FDA, EPA, et al) - this is a threat to most Americans.
Sell competence and our shared interests that depend on a rational, science/expertise based governance.
Safety, security, sanity.

What??? “Keep his ideology anodyne”? His ideology, statements, and behavior have been designed to provoke and outrage those who disagree with him from day 1. This somehow is a special sauce for him. I simply cannot understand this statement at any level.

If Trump receives every vote he received in 2016, where are his new votes coming from?
Clinton voters who switch? Doubtful.
There are fewer old white folks than there was in 2016.
Newer voters are younger, more multi-racial, open to new ideas.
Where are Trump's new votes coming from?
Please advise.

Can't argue with a single word in David Brooks' column today. He nails the Democrats' apparent death wish, to my dismay as well as the dismay of millions of other Americans. At the heart of the problem is Bernie Sanders. If Sanders would only put his ego aside long enough to realize that the majority of Americans are frightened away by anything they perceive as Socialism--that is, if Bernie would only shut his big mouth and go away, the Democratic party might have a chance at recovery.

Fact checkers say Trump told 31 lies in his state of the union speech -- everything from health care to job creation to U.S. energy dominance -- and the list of lies he has told since taking office now exceeds 16,000. Why so many Americans continue to believe this blowhard is not only mystifying but a constant source of mirth overseas.

Your scare techniques about the voters who were Bernie Sanders supporters neglects one big factor: we have all seen the horror this president has created and will NEVER vote for him even if some of us, who know Bernie was robbed last time, voted for him. Also, Hilary is almost gone, if she would just do that. She is a two time loser who has nothing to say.  For the record, I held my nose and voted for her but I understand those of us who love Bernie, who didn’t. Fear not, Trump is not going to get four more years to wreck this country. We have all learned the hard way not to ever vote for him.
How can anyone attack wanting healthcare, a living wage and addressing climate change as radical? Bernie2020
Will the Biden/Bloomberg/Buttigieg Bros support a Sanders-led party?  That's well on the way to becoming the real question.  Thanks for inspiring me to send Bernie another contribution!

Mr.Brooks you are right in your assessment and it made me cry. I do not see any light at end of the tunnel. None of the Democratic candidates has charisma and they are destroying each other for no good reason. They have failed to convince the voters that they have better agenda, policies  and programs. Frankly speaking, a socialist, an extreme left and a gay can not defeat Trump. I urge my fellow Democrats to be realistic and think with your brain not by heart means make intelligent but not emotional decision.

It’s time for all of us as individuals and as journalists to stop trying to predict the future. These predictions are reflections of individual bias, cause anxiety in others and are usually dead wrong. Look at 2016 and the impact of all the prognosticating that took place. Voters stayed home in large numbers because they thought they knew the outcome. Why bother?
An opinion about what is occurring now is welcome. Turning the now into great certainty about tomorrow is a fools errand and a disservice to the electorate.
Good advice.  They won't take it, but nice try anyway.
Let's calm down. The election is a long while away and much can happen and will.
I find it strange that you cite just one poll. This poll finds Trump's approval rating at just 44% and his disapproval at 52% or 8% above. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/

This column needed to say more about the necessity for a moral and social revival. The Republican led Senate just sacrificed its Constitutional right to Executive Oversight. By Executive Order, all Federal Prosecutors have to get permission from the AG to begin any investigation. Truth and justice have become meaningless as the media is labeled as "fake news" and the FBI is now a legion of "dirty cops". How does this square with 75% of the American electorate wanting witnesses and documents in the Senate Impeachment Trial? Many in the Senate said 45's actions were inappropriate and wrong, but not impeachable offences. Huh? Breaking the law by arbitrarily withholding Congressionally approved funds for a country at war is just inappropriate! As one journalist wondered, "How do Republican Senators walk upright when they have no backbone?" Republicans in the East Room laughed and applauded at 45's Revenge Rant. Not good.  This column seems to suggest Americans, like Nero's Rome, just want bread and circuses, and do not care about corruption in Washington. Really!? And I haven't mentioned 45's praise for the "good men" in the White Supremacist's parade in Charlottesville, nor the kidnapped children put in cages and basic hygiene not provided, nor the threats to end the ACA by Texas courts.

So it's a good economy and a criminal Trump or a Democrat who is very progressive or moderately progressive. Mayor Pete would have a good chance of he was 7 years older and not gay. I personally liked the governor of Colorado but he couldn't get traction.

David expresses the fear that many of us share, that Democrats can snatch defeat from the jaws of victory!  Yes they (we) can, and for sure we can't afford it again.

Brooks posits (correctly, BTW) that the boom began with Obama (going from 10% to 4% unemployment is beyond remarkable!) and that Trump had a huge tail wind == correct and helpful.  

Also  seeing Trump's transparency for what it is:  his words & ideas  continuously reflect what he KNOWS is the opposite of correct and true:  so when he says "deep state" we all know that it means "honesty, transparency and competence."  He hates competence (so you fire smart, dedicated people and you hire criminals and unqualified.  He's gotten fat on that for 50 years -- probably has paid zero taxes for the past 20+ years.  When he accused Biden of this or that, we know that he himself and his minions are in fact guilty of that same crime.  So I toast his transparency!   Flip what he says and you see what he fears and what he is admitting in his own life!!  Read his tweets this way and you'll see it is true.

DJT is going to win because the democrats appear to be disorganized, unfocused, and, frankly, unaware. The president gives people the show that they want to watch and his buddies the deals to keep them in extreme wealth. A candidate has to appear that is willing to make Trump look like the Trump that we all know. Get the president to react in a way that makes him act the fool on broadcast media. He is not a good business person - look at all of the failed businesses and bankruptcies. Go to the contractors and people that he has stiffed over the years. I think the solution to a win is a close study of Trump of what he portrays himself as and whom he is in private. It’s all there.
Anyway, who’s going to do that? Any of us democrats got a spine?

Yes, this was the most successful week of the trump reign.  Let us count the ways: He wasn't convicted because he holds a meat cleaver over the heads of the scrawny chickens in the GOP senate. Being not convicted of his crimes rates as a success in trumpneyland, and I guess that's where Brooks must be.

Brooks thinks 49% approval on the handling of the economy is great!  A magnificent victory the likes of which the world has never seen!  But wait, that means that 51% hate, loathe, detest, and despise trump's ample guts.  But in trumpneyland, that's winning, of which I am so tired.

I’m sick of “moderate Republicans” making excuses for their own impotence, blaming the “other tribe” for it. When you get a bully who takes over the playground, blame the other kids? Or roist out the bully by removing him bodily. You fail to stand up to a bully by writing columns and become part of the problem. 

We need campaign finance reform. Else we risk our democracy and union. A president and Congress united to reform campaign finance wouldn’t be enough at this point. The longer the judiciary is populated by conservative judicial appointments, the less likely it is that any congressional attempts at campaign finance reform will be allowed to stand.

By my rough count there are 250 plus days before the election. At the comparable time 4 years ago, Jeb Bush was the likely Republican nominee and the DNC was stacking the deck for Hillary. As we say after bogeying the first hole, “there’s still a lot of golf to be played.” My only prediction is that you can’t predict. Oh, and there will be huge surprises. Scandals, health issues, international crises, etc. So, on the one hand, take a breath, and on the other, get ready for a wild ride.

What is it with Americans and Socialism?  Can't they tell the differences in political systems?  Do we only understand pure Socialism, pure Capitalism, pure Communism, pure Democracy etc.  The most successful countries today are a mix between Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy.   NO Democrat is asking for pure Socialism.  America please educate yourself and stop saying Socialism and get a grip on your fears.  A Social Democracy whereby the basics for the people are Social Programs like Healthcare and Education and Social Security actually works, the rest is Capitalism governed by a Democracy. Not Democracy governed by Capitalism which is what we have now. That balance works better than pure anything. If you took the time to check out how this balance is successfully working in other countries, like my husband's country Switzerland, for example, these stupid fears would go away and we can get off our political constipation and actually make much needed improvements for our citizens.

Mr. Brooks, as such an astute observer of  American society and the cultural influences on our political situation, I would like to see you your turn your attention to the deeply troubling question of why Trump becomes more popular as his corruption, flaunting of the Constitution, and ethical norms are exposed for all to see.  What has happened to American society when we begin to support without questioning and applaud (loudly) his despotic behavior, hatred, and bigotry?  Why are so many putting the blame on those who tried to bring these dangerous acts to light and seek constitutionally prescribed remedy?  How many of us are pumping our fists in the shadow of our enormous national bully, embolden to act out pent up rage and frustration on scapegoats instead of seeking justice and equality?
I'm weary from all your gloom and doom lately and your urging  Dems to come up with all sorts of bills--which, by the way, they have been writing for the past year--fated to sit on McConnell's desk.

The underlying problems that got Trump elected still exist today, which is why a significant % of Americans are now willing to give the Socialist a shot after giving Trump a shot. The real problem is that both of our major parties are run by extremists and are also corrupt and incompetent. Neither party is going to “save” us. We need new political parties. The first one that forms a consensus among the majority of Americans who reject both wings of extremists will win for the next 50 years

“... it looks like the Democratic primary battle is going to go on for a while.” No kidding David. Exactly ONE state has voted. Please reign in your impatience. It is not a coronation. We Democrats are also unlikely to choose a candidate that meets all of your Republican conservative expectations. Get over it.

Hello, David Brooks.  Coming back home?  Of course the economy is strong and good for people.  What were you thinking?  Of course impeachment was a self-inflicted wound on the NYT and your never-Trumper crowd.  What were you thinking?  Of course Trump is surging.  Did you not read the tea leaves?

The betting markets have Trump at the moment as a 59 percent-plus favorite to win.  That number is rising.   

You can have your haughty principles, Mr. Brooks, and, yes, Trump is something of a crass boor, flaunting convention (to  the extent there is a Twitter convention for presidents).   

But has it not occurred to you, Mr. Brooks, that certain peoples have been ostracized for similar supposed characteristics?
Let me see—the economy is great because of Trump’s policies—sooo let’s hope the economy falters, so Trump will look bad?  That’s really sick and hateful.  DOW 30,000–Trump 2020!

America, in general, is a violent, racist country populated by many, many not very bright people.  The kind of people our founding fathers didn't want near an election. Our excuse for a president embodies these traits in spades.  That is why he won in 2016 (along with Electoral College help and voter suppression) and that's why he may win again.  It's really that simple.

Okay, up front we should reject the premise that this election is the Democrats' to "give away" in the first place. As Brooks notes, it is exceptionally difficult to unseat *any* incumbent president. When it has happened in recent decades (Bush 41 and Carter), it required both a recession and some type of unforced error on the incumbent's part. (In Bush's case, ongoing denial that we were in a recession until it was too late; for Carter, his perceived ineptitude - fair or not - at handling the hostage crisis).
We aren't in a recession, and it's unlikely - not impossible - that we'll be in one nine months from now. And Trump also seems keenly aware that avoidance of a major foreign policy crisis is essential to his re-election.
I'm not a Bernie guy by any means, but I do think that he brings a moral clarity which the moderate wing - which I'm normally inclined to support - often lacks. Yes, the economy is doing great if you have a 401k, but...why is the min. wage still only $7.25, why is college increasingly unaffordable, why is daycare increasingly unaffordable, why do we still have no guaranteed parental leave, why is health care increasingly unaffordable, why do Amazon, Netflix, et al, pay no income tax? It's not "class warfare" to highlight inequities that are almost entirely unique to our country.

The article raises good points about how the apparent success of "capitalism" will be used by Republicans in the campaign.  Many Americans will buy this argument hook line and sinker. However, I would like to refer more thoughtful readers to a classic article by Henry Mintzberg in the Harvard Business Review 24 years ago, "Managing Government, Governing Management," which predicts what might be amiss in such thinking and began: 

“Capitalism has triumphed.” That was the pat conclusion reached in the West as, one by one, the communist regimes of Eastern Europe began to fall. It has become such an article of faith that we have become blind to its effects. Those effects are highly negative—indeed, dangerous—because the conclusion itself is wrong. In my view, we have confounded the whole relationship between business and government, and we had best clear it up before we end up no better off than the Eastern Europeans once were.

Okay, I'm getting a little tired of the MSM citing the latest Gallup poll and ignoring all others.  No doubt that Trump's approval rating in the new poll was his highest ever.  There's also no doubt that 49% is reflected in no other (except Rasmussen, which also shows 49% approval but it over-includes Republicans in its sample and thus always skews pro-Trump by 4 or 5 points).

If we see a slew of polls with the same numbers (excluding Rasmussen), there might be reason to believe a major shift is occurring.  But Trump's polling average is still showing about 44% approve, 51% disapprove.  High for Trump but not indicative of a major shift.

Any poll, no matter how high quality the methodology is, will be incorrect about 5% of the time.  Sometimes, even when you do everything right, your sample of 1000 people just ends up not being reflective of the opinions of hundreds of millions.  That's why one should rely on polling averages, not a single poll, when the evidence suggests that the result is an outlier.

Check out the polling average and adjustments at 538.

Mr. Brooks' warning should be noted.  But panic based upon a single, apparently aberrant poll should not.

What should the Democrats' focus be? (NYT Feb. 7) Health care? Immigration? Income disparity? I just drove to Concord, NH uncertain about which candidate or issue I cared most about. Then Tom Steyer nailed Democrats' elusive issue—climate change. 

Flames are engulfing large swaths of Australia and California. Hurricanes are uprooting houses and entire communities are on the verge of being swallowed by rising seas. Our runaway climate can (and should) generate the same fear as Kennedy's focus on the missile crisis and Nixon's war on crime. I support advocating for a "moral and social revival" in this (temporary) age of prosperity. But Steyer's impassioned call to tackle climate change is compelling and visceral. Climate impacts everyone. It coalesces issues of immigration, health, income disparity, jobs, and more. How could there be a more compelling and unifying banner for Democrats to rally under?

Try this:

Think of the year when your father or mother was born.  Quite likely, FDR was President, right?  (My Mom was born in 1932.)  Now, draw a time-line from then until now, and make a little tick-mark each time the White House occupancy switches from one party to another.  Not each time the PRESIDENT changes, but each time one PARTY displaces the other.  

Now, how many times is the time between two adjacent party-switch ticks only four years, not eight, not twelve, not more than twelve?

Because if you are betting on a Democrat to win in November, that is what you are betting on: one party (Republican, in this case) will have taken the White House from the other party (Dems in this case) in 2016, and then had to return it four years later, in 2020.  

How many four-year-only party-occupancies have there been, since 1932?

ANSWER: only ONE!!  The Dems' occupancy from 1976 until 1980.  

And how many times has the White House changed from one party to another, since 1932?  NINE.  

So if you bet on a Dem winning in November, you will be betting on a second occurrence of an event which has happened only in one out of nine cases.  

Don't bet more than you can afford to lose.

Even when you’re making a decent salary in a “right to work” state, there is almost no guarantee the work going to be there for long. And everywhere you go, more good paying jobs are “gig economy” jobs with no long term guarantee or union support. This adds to stress, and when you get sick, the health insurance market can have its way with you. The veneer of our “booming” economy is paper thin and peeling.

On the "principles" here, Brooks could have written this in a political science class in 1963.  The world has changed.  May I suggest Mr. Brooks go back to Yale and listen to some of the scientists there.
  He might also read John Rawls (1971) on distributive Justice.  Economic inequality is not inevitable.

That Sanders voter went to Trump say a lot about the political awareness of the American voting public. In what universe is Trump the default candidate after Sanders? In what universe is Trump a better choice than Biden?

"Wages are rising. The typical family income is higher than it has ever been."

What world are you in? Family, friends, and neighbors work 2 jobs to make ends meet. Rents are out of control..

Capitalism does not call for the dismantling of the American government as Trump does.  Trumpism can coexist with Capitalism, but is not Capitalism's champion.  The fault in this editorial is that it does not address the many aspects of Trumpism that most upset his opponents.

I am 65....I have pretty much seen it all, but not this.  This is madness.  The middle has crumbled, and unless Congress finds their spine, a revolution or war may be the only way this gets resolved..  Life will never be the same for me and those of my age.  I pray my kids will not still be living under the ravages of madmen when they approach 65.  Dems....please...I beg you, no matter who gets nominated, vote for that candidate.

Yes David, but are Americans "socially mobile, caring and interdependent"? No. I see America as episodes of "Survivor."
Too few people care about the rule of law. Or bed-rock values like compassion, fair play. McConnell got away with denying Obama's SC nominee a hearing. How? Because he could, and knew nobody cared.

Trump is going to win if the Democratic platform is "Democratic Socialism." Democrats need to sit down next to that former steelworker who's now making $12 an hour with no benefits at the propane store and explain to him why he will personally be better off with a Democrat in the White House. He would be, but they need to be able to articulate it in a convincing way.

Actually the economy is on life support as Jerome Powell adds 60 billion dollars a month in liquidity together with other central banks.  The 538 approval average is 43% and disapproval average is about 54%.  The yield curve is negative especially between 2 years and 10 years suggesting recession.  The stock market is over bought.  Bernie is bad news for Democrats but Pete and/or Michael may pull it off.  Trump is starting to show prosecutorial traits of dictators like going after Hunter Biden.

Oddly too, winning against an adversary like Trump should be the easiest thing in the world.

The problem isn’t Trump, nor is it really, quite exactly, the Democrats.

The problem is the electorate. That is to say, the voters. Which is just another way of saying, Americans.

Other nations have problems too, but the center there seems to be holding, there. Well, okay, maybe not Britain, and certainly not really Russia. Italy has issues too. But lots of nations are doing fine. In the Netherlands, the Dutch are doing fine, even if their record is not 100% perfect. 

In the Netherlands, it is very small stuff that is getting better. Bike paths and public transportation. And other stuff too. The quality of life there is actually getting better, not worse, like elsewhere.

Eventually East Side Access under Grand Central will open, in December 2022 ( ? ), but that has been a long, long time coming, and more stuff like that is needed. That is the sort of sustainable stuff that makes life better. All the stuff to which Trump is opposed.

So great, Trump is borrowing a trillion Dollars a year, and spending it. That makes things look good, but it isn’t sustainable.

Bernie Sanders is not "to far left" - his concerns are the same concerns shared by a majority of Americans from all walks of life. The DNC needs to wake up to this fact.  I had considered myself a 'centrist' for many years, but given all that has been happening in our country recently, I feel that Bernie is precisely what we need to set ourselves back on the correct path.  He has my full support, and I believe he is the only viable candidate that can rally the votes and enthusiasm needed to defeat Trump.

Of course dems are going to give it away.  That is exactly what they have been doing since Reagan and the Nixon southern strategy.
I see many hopeful predictions anticipating the demise of the GOP.  We all know there is no one to finish them off.
Everything the GOP has done to this nation and the constitution has gone all but unopposed by the dems.   There is no hope in that direction

"Only 53 percent of Sanders voters say they will certainly support whomever is the Democratic nominee. This is no idle threat."

Democrats freely made choices around their "big tent" idea addressing the self interests of a number of groups. 

There should be no surprise that resulting competing interests and ideologies inside the party will naturally divide within the party at crunch time.

Maybe the democratic candidate can run on honesty,  decency, and having a moral compass. Maybe run on building the country up, not raking perceived enemies over the coals. Maybe he or she can run on keeping our environment, water, air, and earth, clean and healthy. Maybe he or she can run on respecting our security agencies and diplomats working to keep the country safe. Maybe run on repairing our relationships with allies and putting adversarial autocrats on notice. Maybe promising and then following through with infrastructure, green energy, and some solutions to student debt, healthcare access, and resetting the flawed and unfair tax structure.  Hey, that's what all the democratic candidates are running on.

I'd like to agree, and add a comment about the Ukraine.  The popular wisdom about the Ukraine since the fall of the Soviet Union has been that it would be the first to rejoin Russia.  Languages so close that they can talk to each other without interpreters, millions of intermarried couples, same religion, same history.  So a sensible, honest  American relationship with the last president of the Ukraine, and the present one, would have been an acknowledgement that Mr. Putin meant it when he said that he felt the end of the Soviet union was the greatest tragedy of the 20th century, and that he was simply more determined than the Western world on the subject of Ukrainian independence.  And we were not likely to fight a world war on the issue, except by accident.  My point?  I have been subjected to listening to utter nonsense on the subject for months now, and like many American voters, I'm tired of being asked to get passionate about nonsense.  The first party that convinces me it's interested in lowering drug prices, or rebuilding the nation's bridges and highways, probably gets my vote.
David, when the cost of victory is the United States' system of checks and balances, who exactly is the winner?

"That suggests that Democrats should acknowledge that the economy has done well since the Obama recovery in 2009. They should argue that this is the time to take advantage of prosperity to begin a moral and social revival. This is the year to run a values campaign, one that champions policies to make America more socially mobile, caring and interdependent"

Isn't this exactly what the plans for expanding health care, reducing student debt, paying for public college, expanding the social safety net, investing in renewable energy, and promoting a reduction in wealth inequality are? Seems like Mr. Brooks is not seeing the forest for the trees built by his inherent bias.

Yes Americans care about their own self interests, lives and needs. My guess is that is why candidates make promises about healthcare and even free universities while making "the rich" pay for benefits for others. 

This really should not be news for anyone.
It's Bloomberg or Trump that's the choice.  I don't think the Democrats' base has "woke" to this fact yet.
It never occurs to David Brooks that Americans are optimistic because they see the end of Trump's term in the near future.

The article is worded to imply that some Sanders supporters didn't merely stay home in 2016; they actually voted - for Trump. Am I misreading? Some are kids, and therefore inclined to be petulant, but isn't it reasonable to assume they'll at least remain genuinely neutral in 2020?

Then there are differential ethnic birth and death rates shifting the electorate toward the Democrats (if not genuinely to the left on certain issues).

With their opposition to guns, it'll be hard for Democrats to shoot themselves in the foot. But they're planning to use a cannon anyway.

“The unemployment rate is the lowest in decades. Wages are rising. The typical family income is higher than it has ever been.”

The unemployment rate is the lowest in decades for dead-end jobs. Wages are sloooowly rising. The typical family income is tight and has been since 2009. I appreciate Mr. Brooks’ strong medicine but these little nuggets that he throws in to subtly advance the GOP narrative tend to add a rancid note to the brew.

Lastly, if Bernie and his supporters run away with the election more power to them. If they win, great. If they lose, Progressivism will be dead for another 75 years. A pretty high stakes game to play with a party that only lost the 2016 election by 75,000 votes and won handily in 2018. Is it time to throw the baby out with the bath water because some baristas got woke?

The economy is clearly being manipulated, going back to the holiday season. The U.S.and China have both suffered to some extent in the similarly made-up "war". The economy is also very fragile in the wake of severe weather events. If Dorian had struck the S.E. coast of Florida with 185 MPH winds, I can't even conceive of the chaos that would have caused. I'm sure every region of the country is in the process of evaluating risks and procedures should "something" might occur. But there are other things, too. The POTUS must NOT continue to manipulate the military, ordering foolhardy actions, and equally foolhardy withdrawals. This is the greatest "immediate" risk that BOTH parties in Congress must agree to. If we can't depose him, tie his hands. Withhold funding. He is an unstable, imaginary-genius
living in CEO heaven. But he's not our boss, and we are not his employees.

Instead, the Democrats quibble over who said what to whom two years ago. Don't forget that they would also like to remind us all who was friends with whom 20 years ago or how someone voted 30 years ago. Telling us the political affiliation of your brothers doesn't do much for me either. And if you want to tell us all how everything will soon be free but neglect to tell us how you will pay for that when our national charge card is already maxed out, that would be helpful. And, by the way, saying "folks" in every other sentence demonstrates you are out of touch with younger voters. 

To me the only two candidates who seem routed in reality are Amy and Pete.

I bet David Brooks voted for Trump in 2016.  I don’t want to bother to look it up because I don’t trust whatever Brooks has said about his vote.  I just bet, though, in the privacy of the voting booth Brooks chose Trump.

SANDERS OR WARREN?
The upper middle class in America would agree with Mr. Brooks analysis, but not the lower middle class. The economic prosperity Mr. Brooks refers to or the wage increase of $10-15 per hour was due 15 years ago. I would say that the vibrancy of our society ( values, law and order, hope for change etc.) is the one responsible for keeping Americans optimistic about the future. While Trump and the GOP-pers may appear to be winning, the majority of Americans still think the country is ready for major changes. Only Sanders or Warren can bring such changes to fruition.

"The typical family income is higher than it has ever been."

Say what? Where does this originate? Who says? Well, if this is true, then I guess we should announce problem solved, we can all go home and watch Netflix into the next century.  Color me mystified.

Does this mean income is higher in non-inflation adjusted dollars? 

The economic stats I've seen indicate that the Trump economy is little better, and in some measures worse or no better, than the long recovery under Obama. And, wages still haven't risen enough to give average wage earners a break.

Brooks is finally realizing that the Establishment has lost.  The electorate shed the Establishment using Trump. Soon the electorate will further shed the Establishment using Sanders.

The only question left is whether the Establishment wants to side with Trump to continue siphoning wealth away from the citizenry, or wants to side with Sanders to fix this country by spreading the wealth?

(Hint:  it doesn't matter what the Establishment wants -- just ask Bloomberg's wasted $millions.)

Mr. Brooks might be surprised to know that impeachment has very much been a "topic of conversation" amongst my friends and family. The ugly reality that our opinions would not alter the political calculus of Senate Republicans, only meant that those conversations were depressing in nature, not that they didn't occur.

The Sanders voters who switched to Trump were anti-establishment types and not necessarily liberal. 

The "blow it up Bernie" voters who saw him as a counter to the status quo - who's name was Hillary. Those dissatisfied with the state of the recovery from the great recession. 

So, naturally they drifted to Trump or probably didn't vote or went for third party. 
Let's see those stats. 

As for Gallup, I'll have to go deeper and see their metrics for that one poll. Other polls are still showing Trump down double digits on approval in the same time frame. 
(The Economist and Reuters polls)

My bet- by April Gallup will have him down at least 9 points again. 

The Dems need to assure people that it's OK to let go of Trump. To put him aside. 
We'll all be fine and think how nice "normal" will feel again. 

Throw in his own words about cutting Medicare and Social Security, his big lie about protecting pre-existing conditions and a little nuclear war danger and the net calculus will be simple:

It's just fine to kick him out.

People just say that want to defeat Trump, but they don’t actually look at who can defeat Trump based on who is pulling in Trump voters. (And I don’t mean Bernie supporters from 2016 who voted Trump as a protest vote.)

The strange thing about Trump is he is a strongman who relies on his rural, white base for support without actually helping them. This is not how it works for most strongmen.

The strange thing about most of the Dem candidates? Only one of them is addressing the malaise felt by the people who turned toward Trump thinking that maybe this outsider would “drain the swamp” and take care of them.

That candidate is Yang.

This is why he has a more diverse group of supporters than any other candidate pulling in moderates from both sides, progressives, and independents.

The Vegas odds are on Yang vs Trump. He is likable, smart, funny, seems to like everyone, and has a beautiful family. He seems like a person who would enjoy spending time with all kinds of people. (If you haven’t looked into him start with the N.H. town hall he did last night.)

But he isn’t polling well which leads me to believe that defeating Trump isn’t the real goal for most people. The real goal is having your ideas or candidate defeat Trump. 

And all that is going to lead to is more Trump.

David Brooks is 100% correct in my view and I am anti Trump.

The democrats MUST put forth a candidate that appears confident and with a message that appeals to  or inspires the voters. Some of the goody-goody messages from Warren and Sanders are not making a serious impact.

They might sound good on the surface with " free this and free that"  but true voters see this as somewhat superficial.

They have time to get their act together but frankly, we should be a little concerned if we want Trump out of the White House.

Gallup's 49% approval for Trump is a clear outlier.  According to pollingreport.com,  13 national polls on Trump were taken in the month of January.  The average approval rating was 43.5%.  Gallup's 49% was a full 3% higher than any other.  And there were three polls taken subsequent to Gallup's, averaging only 44% approval.
Yet Brooks seizes on the ONE poll that gives Trump a positive spin.  That tells you more about Brooks than it does about Trump.

Like all incumbent presidents, Trump starts with a 60% chance of being reelected.  Since his plan is to lose the popular vote and win the electoral college by design, we will see.  There are people who will vote blue no matter who.  Will they carry the day?  Ask me on the first Wednesday in November.  A lot can happen in 9 months.  Watch this space.

Finally. Iv'e been waiting for someone to wake up and discuss this. The fact that two of the democratic candidates who are frontrunners in this race are campaigning on blowing up the system that right now seems to be working superbly (ie capitalism) is just an insane play by the democrats and I have been struggling to figure out why they think this is going to work. Even the more moderate ones (ie Biden and Buttigieg ) are too often talking about how the economy isn't working (it is!). 

Honestly, I couldn't bring myself to vote for Trump in the first election for the obvious reasons, but at this point I'll most certainly hold my nose and do it. 

Here's the key - the fact that the democrats seem to think that they can convince a majority of Americans that Donald Trump's policies aren't working for us is the epitome of elitism. At least thats how it feels. Because normal intelligent people see fabulous economic numbers, new trade deals that seem to be working in our favor, strategies in the middle east that (if you look hard enough for the pieces written by honest journalists) are being at least praised for originality, an immigration mess that seems to be righting itself, tax cuts that are putting money in peoples pockets. 

And we are being told how badly we need not only incremental change, but to blow up the system or we're doomed! It doesn't get much more insulting. 

I'm no fan of the man, but I see Democrats missing all the lessons of 2016 and they're going to lose.

Understanding someone's troubles is not accepting their values. True equivalence is a mutual lack of empathy between coast and heartland, nothing more. Brooks wants pluralism not segregation. But he thinks saying how disagreements over this map onto regional or class differences will delay empathy's development, and that proportioning blame is counterproductive. He wants to expand economic opportunity in rural communities to temper their historic racism. More direct is his support of reparations for racism. These ideas are as materialist as those of his redistributionist critics, and offer an olive branch. But Sunday school teaches that evil precedes repentance or hellfire, not a bigger paycheck. So in addition to reparations, we need public confessions of guilt as in South Africa after apartheid. Criminalize voter suppression laws and give the authors amnesty for admitting their wrongs before victims. Brooks fears a vindictiveness flowing from perceived moral superiority, but victims can lose their taste for revenge when perpetrators speak truth. (See the ending of Polanski's Death & The Maiden.) Materialists have trouble understanding this. Weaving the social fabric requires a truth commission like South Africa's, and reformation or destruction of the political party that tore it. Reconciliation is not revenge, but it hurts. No Lincoln without John Brown, no sweet Jesus without John the Baptist.
For all those people who point to Europe with all its social spending....You do realize it's only possible because the US has been paying for their defense for years.

Not so fast, Mr Brooks. Trump’s election in 2016 was a shock to almost everyone, but don’t be so sure it will happen again. The Gallup poll is just one poll based on interviews of only about 1000 people. According to the poll averages on Five Thirty Eight he is still the least popular president in decades. 

Trump may have gotten a small bump from impeachment but how will it play out in the longer run when, inevitably, new details of his corruption comes out?  What if he is caught trying to cheat again? What if Obamacare is struck down and health care chaos ensues?  What if the long overdue crash of the stock market arrives? Weren’t the recession indicators flashing a few months ago?

Point is, there are far too many variables to be making predictions about the unpredictable with nine months to go until the election. Let’s not let pessimism and despair drag us all down just yet.

Anyone who repeats that Trump’s approval has supposedly increased to 49%, based on one, outlier poll and proceeds to draw conclusions from it instantly loses my respect and makes me stop reading their column.

Google “RCP Trump” and you will see that in an average of all the polls, Trump’s approval hasn’t budged above 45%. Impeachment had no effect on his supporters. It has been that way his entire Presidency. As for whether impeachment hurts or benefits Republicans, we won’t know that until we see the Senate elections in the fall.

"Democrats may wind up in a position in which they can’t nominate Bernie Sanders because he’s too far left."
Too far left for who?  The 117,000 Sanders primary voters  in Pennsylvania who went for Trump in the general?  The 48,000 in Michigan or the 51,300 in Wisconsin?  If nominating Sanders will keep those voters from voting for Trump, the Democratic Party will reclaim the White House.
Who cares if Michael Bloomberg's friends on Wall Street don't like Sanders.  Are there 800,000 of them?  That's how many New Yorkers would have to switch to give New York to Trump.

"Only 53 percent of Sanders voters say they will certainly support whomever is the Democratic nominee. ... In short, Sanders voters helped elect Trump."

This second sentence does not follow the first. Bernie was able to attract potential Trump supporters, Trump won because Clinton was the nominee, he would have lost of Bernie was. 

Bernie did not help get Trump elected, Trump won because Bernie was not nominated.

Mr. Brooks, you don't mean to say that the middle and the lower classes in the United States are not suffering from outrageous income inequality, or that Democrats should not address climate change or nuclear proliferation, do you?  On the surface the economy appears to be doing well, but below the surface the oligarchs and the corporations and their stockholders are making all the money.

Corporate capitalism is not working for the majority of people, and I am one of them.  Corporate capitalism is making a joke of our democracy.  What's the point of having free speech if nobody listens unless you have an exorbitant amount of money behind you?  How does that adhere to democratic principles?

David Brooks, how can you say in the same breath Donald Trump and morality. He has singlehandedly shattered the belief that America represented a moral beacon to the world and our children. You claim that he simply needs to state the “successes” of his administration, whether real or imagined, and he will easily coast to victory.

There is a critique of American capitalism that needs to be hammered home every day. How can the “wealthiest” and most innovative nation not be able to provide healthcare to all of its citizens? Basic housing? Employable education? 

We as Democrats have many candidates, many choices, to oppose the President, but we have one message that all resonate...America is failing its people, its future, and its morals by re-electing this menace and his cronies in the House, Senate, and state houses nationwide.

I for one am hopeful of a coming national reckoning.

I don't understand this article. It states that Sanders can't be elected because he is "too left" and then goes on to say that many Sanders voters voted for Trump.  The article also seems to worry or complain, as best I can guess, that the Democratic primary season is not over yet, when it has barely begun: "There is no Democratic transcender."  In any case, the left wing of the party got 48% and increasingly people like Robert Reich and Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor are noticing that the CENTRIST Democrats helped elect Trump, not the LEFT.  Therefore, I can only conclude that not being centrist will help defeat Trump and that we need to win over Democrats who voted for Trump, i.e. Sanders voters and (something Mr. Brooks has ignored) erstwhile Obama voters.

Short answer is yes, the Democrats are going to just give it to Trump.
4 more years of this will of course be a disaster. By here's the silver lining/some reason for optimism: The fact that the economy is still doing well does not just make it more difficult to defeat Trump. Voting him out of office before the economy tanks would make the victory Pyrrhic for the Democrats. He would be left off the hook, free to continue claiming he is a stable genius - and of course the crash and the upcoming recession will become the responsibility of the next president. You and I know that what's happening now is a Ponzi scheme, more or less. They keep printing money and burning it - the deficit has exploded, in times of prosperity no less, so is the national debt, they keep borrowing more than we'll ever be able to repay - and frankly the whole thing is running on borrowed time. But try as you might to explain this to most voters  - you can't blame them for not taking your word for it, when their income has actually gone up and they seem to be doing ok. But it will crash sooner or later. And Trump has to own it. I know that was a questionable kind of optimism - but I'm not very optimistic by nature. 
Oh, and another optimistic idea I have: if the GOP is now the party of Trump, and the Dems are on the way to become the party of Bernie - maybe decent centrists - Romneys and Buttigieges will come together and form a viable third party? A sane candidate in 2024? (I'm dreaming, I know)
The wealthy made this possible by holding wages down for 40 years.  And a year or two of modest wage growth will not fix that. You should not be one bit surprised Bernie is so popular now.

Bernie Sanders supporters voted for Trump to spite Hilary. She was seen as being in the pocket of Wall Street which was a central message of his campaign in 2016 - "the system is rigged". Trump gave the impression that he was no beholden to Wall Street. Now they want free college and free health care. Trump is not going to give them either of those. At least the moderate dems will do a better job than Trump would with health care. It will be interesting to see if they stay away from the polls. If Bernie is not the candidate I think it's still going to be important for him that Trump is defeated. He'll put more of an endorsement behind whomever is the candidate this time around, and his supporters will follow. Everyone thought Trump was a joke in 2016. They know better now.

Talk about great political oratory!  I got all the way to the penultimate paragraph thinking "Wow, David Brooks is going to endorse a radical platform??" and then came the "class war" sentence, right at the end, and I knew I'd been had.

Yeah, for many people, not the really poor, but many people, the economy is a little better, when compared to a year ago, rather than to 2007.  So, great!  Now is the time for Medicare for All!  Now is the time for free public universities and community colleges!

These things shouldn't be "class war," but they are.  Why?  Not because radicals enjoy class war.  Because the rich are so greedy that even in good times they can't bring themselves to let a little bit of economic security trickle down to the 99%.

“They should argue that this is the time to take advantage of prosperity to begin a moral and social revival. This is the year to run a values campaign, one that champions policies to make America more socially mobile, caring and interdependent.”

Bernie’s stump speech.

Read James David Barber's "Pulse of Politics." Brooks has hit perfectly on Barber's organic theory of presidential elections. A down in the mud fighting election is usually followed by an election of conscience -- the way a family fight is followed by contrition and vows to do better. If Barber is right (and he isn't always) the winning candidate will treat this election as a call to moral rectitude. The losing candidate will be fighting and punching and gouging and the voters will be going a different direction. It sounds like someone in Donald John's orbit had the Barber idea for the State of the Union speech but by today those moral sounding words had been lost -- of course.

I’m surprised to read this half-baked op-Ed by Brooks. Sanders supporters voted for Clinton in the general in larger numbers than Clinton supporters voted for Obama in ‘08. 
 Why not mention Jill Stein’s voters? This analysis leaves entirely too much out.

2016 was an election cycle for disruptors, there were two: Sanders and Trump. The GOP allowed Trump his due. The DNC stole the nomination from Sanders and handed it to the most establishment candidate possible. The disruptor won. Of course, the Democratic Party pulled the same stunt against Sanders in Iowa which will further sow distrust among the grassroots and the young voters everybody keeps complaining that don’t vote.

If Trump wins, like he won last time, it will have everything to do with the DNC’s corruption and their contempt for the will of their grassroots, not with Sanders or his supporters.

Brooks' logic is an inversion of rationality. The high percentage of Sanders voters who voted for Trump in the Rust Belt jibes with the exit polls in the region in 2016, which demonstrated that Sanders would have crushed Trump there head-to-head, and thus won going away nationally. The same logic applies this year. If Dems nominate Sanders, he and he alone will beat Trump in the Rust Belt. That by itself should win the election for Sanders. But on top of his advantage with Rust Belt working-class whites, all women for choice and blacks "have no choice," as Jill Biden would say, but to vote for Sanders, whether he's their preferred candidate or not, since the alternative is four more years of Trump, which would wipe out huge swaths of all the legal gains of women and blacks in the liberal courts of the past 60 years. The key to beating Trump is the white Rust Belt, period. Bernie is by far the strongest candidate in that region, just as he was in 2016, especially since Trump's policies have led to manufacturing and farm recession there for average people, not growth. Vote Bernie, if beating Trump is your first priority. Vote Bloomberg if you want to re-elect Trump.

Around 330 million people in America now.  A only few thousand caucus attendees in very unrepresentative Iowa are supposed to determine who gets the Democratic nomination and win the presidency for the 330 million living in America. All the time, energy, money, and media hype entailed in the Iowa caucuses defies common sense in the American democracy. The Iowa caucuses is nothing less than a corruption of American democracy.

Sometimes you have to wonder if the Democrats are channeling the spirit of George McGovern. Yes, lets nominate the most liberal person we can find! We don't need any swing voters or conservatives. A moderate candidate that isn't a true believer in "democratic socialism" is icky! So what if the democratic party, then perceived as extremely liberal, only won a single state in the 1972 election. No worries!

One reason Trump won is that rural and working class whites (not to mention blacks and hispanics) did not feel part of this economic miracle or the identity politics of the democratic party, as used by Hillary in her campaign, which mostly appealed to the upper middle class, as well as Oscar winners. Bernie is the candidate best positioned to split the working class from Trump, but the Clintonians despise him. Trump's economy does not work for most people, and wealth inequality is still underminding this country - thus Trump may win, again.
Thank you for sharing this important data about the "Bernie bros": "In short, Sanders voters helped elect Trump." That's why I will not vote for Sanders in the primary

I am retired, on SS and a small pension. My taxes increased a lot. They always do under a Republican presidency. They are so busy giving tax breaks to the wealthy. Yet the little guys keep voting for them. Hillary won the popular vote. Trump won the EC. I now detest the EC. It will takes years for the people and the government to recover. If a Democrat is elected taxes will have to be raised. It always happens. And people blame the Democrats instead of the party that is at fault. Truly deplorable. But the rich are happy.
Economically, my "felt reality" is that for the first time in a decade, my taxes went up last year.  My "felt reality" is that my husband hasn't had a raise, COLA or merit, in six years.

Egypt and Argentina have economic systems that basically work.  They survive from year to year and decade to decade.  Yet they are also basically broken.

Democrats believe that capitalism is basically working, but that it needs a basic overhaul or makeover.  We are becoming more and more of an oligopoly, and income and wealth gaps are great and rising.  

Trump does not believe capitalism is basically working; he thinks it is near perfect and would be even better with government power reduced.  Lawsuits would still be possible, but they would be decided by money and the ability of the powerful to outwait the less powerful.   Trump wants an economy where businessmen like him do well, laws are enforced and businessmen like those bankers who stopped lending him money do less well.

When 60% of Americans don't have $1,000.00 saved for an emergency, that is not a good economy.  Mr. Brooks, if you can remember back to the government shutdown, many government workers did not have enough saved to last even one month without risking foreclosure.  This implies these men and women were living paycheck to paycheck.  The fact that so few Americans have any significant savings is not good economic news, especially in the longer term.  What will happen when these Americans reach retirement age?  In the more immediate term, people pushed to the edge rarely feel charitable towards others.  As a consumer economy, if people cannot afford to consume, what then happens?  This is not a strong economy, it is weak.  We need to measure our economy differently.  Rather than looking at raw unemployment numbers, we need to consider wages and how much it costs to live in a specific area, and the savings per person.  Such information will provide a much more accurate snapshot of the economy.

There are three issues that are important to the American electorate:

Health care
Health care
Health care

That was the primary winning issue in the 2018 mid-term elections that gave back to the Dems the House majority.  It was the most important issue Democratic voters noted on all the exit polls.

And it is still the most important issue.  What are the Democrats waiting for?

None of the presidents-elect cited--Kennedy, Nixon, and Trump--ran against an incumbent president. Never before have I responded to an opinion in the NYT but this column is so outrageous that I must.

"The unemployment rate is the lowest in decades." 

That is irrelevant. People who are unemployed longer than 26 weeks are not counted. There are many thousands maybe even millions in that group. Basically, if you are over 45 and you become unemployed, you can't find a job with a decent wage and life as you knew it ends. Statistics do not reflect this. Admittedly, this problem is less of a problem than it was during the Great Recession but it is a huge problem.

Add to that that the cost of living, especially housing, has gone up astronomically, so you can't afford to move. If you get rid of your house, you can never afford another one. So you are stuck where you are. This is (also) not covered in government statistics.

"Wages are rising."

Not in my paycheck. Not since 2005. That is right... 15 years of 3-4% increase in expenses, and no raise. It hurts big time. 

"The typical family income is higher than it has ever been."

Totally incorrect. I personally do not know anyone for whom that is true. All my friends and co-workers are in the same boat.

"Democrats, by contrast, have congregated around the message that capitalism is fundamentally broken and that the economy is bad."

That is correct (and I am not a Democrat). Evidence given above at least from my perspective. Then again, I am not sure Democrats have a feasible plan. But is it broken? You bet!

FYI: A bit of history from Wikipedia:

Impeachment Process Against Richard Nixon

On November 4, 1973, Senator Edward Brooke became the first congressional Republican to publicly urge President Nixon to resign. That same week, several newspapers, including The Atlanta Journal, The Denver Post, The Detroit News and The New York Times, published editorials also urging him to resign. Time magazine, in the first editorial in 50 years of publication, did so as well, declaring that the president "has irredeemably lost his moral authority" to govern effectively, and that Nixon "and the nation have passed a tragic point of no return."
