Votes of conscience are easy when the cause is already lost. Offering to testify when there's no chance you'll be called is easy too.

I suspect this notion was behind the Speaker's early reluctance to impeach.  Still, as long as they're in the majority, House Democrats can continue hearings on the President's deeds... and his fitness for office.

Senator Susan Collins taught Trump there will be no consequences in the Senate for anything he does. Well, the McConnell speech during Wednesday’s finale was pretty stunning. “Our adversaries seek to divide us against each other,” the majority leader told his colleagues, warning them not to become “consumed with partisan rancor.”

I will never cease to be amazed at the absurd and outrageous statements Mitch McConnell makes time after time, with completely seriousness. Ms. Collins, you've done the dog until it's become pointless.  This was the one time you specially should have skipped it.  I know that you and Mitch Romney can't stand each other but, as you yourself said, he did the right thing by voting against Trump, and he's going to go through a lot of pain because of it, even though he's really rich and everything. Gail, for once you are not being cynical enough.  Romney is positioning himself to be a "centrist" Republican candidate for president in 2020 just in case Trump finally does something the Senate can't ignore.  Bernie & Biden have shown that age and previous failures are no obstacle to running, and Mitch is probably OK with having a Plan B now that Trump is completely unleashed.

Great column. Like Gail Collins, I've been struck by Romney's capacity for cynicism for a long time. This is a man whose positions on climate have now turned a full 540 degrees. A man who pretended not to recognize his own RomneyCare plan when he became the GOP nominee in 2012. And in his scoffing at the "47 percent," the moochers who get VA benefits, SSDI or Medicare, he pandered to the worst instincts of rich GOP donors. But when it counted most, Mitt Romney alone stood up. I will not forget that and neither should the history of this awful time.

Did Susan Collins merely state that Trump had "learned a lesson" or did she say what kind of lesson?  I agree with her that he did learn a lesson:  that he is as unfettered in doing what he wants as his idol, Vlad Putin.  Now he knows that, with her obsequiousness and servile devotion to McConnell and her party, nothing can touch him.
The only thing I find mildly amusing is that Trump will remember her ridiculously timid comment about learning a lesson and he does not forgive.

Yes, Trump does not "learn" - because he already "knows" everything he needs to know, no one knows as much as he does and learning is just not  something he needs to do.  If he did learn anything, it was next time make sure no one has any idea of what he's up to.

Mainer here. I agree with all of this, of course, but I have to take exception to the remark that we haven't noticed that our 'senator’s political independence tends to work best when the matter at hand is meaningless.' Yes, we have noticed, bigly. A campaign is underway as we speak, to boot her out. In the last election many dems supported her, and she kept her seat. Never again. My bumper sticker: ByeBye Susan.

Collins stands only for her re-election, just so she gets to be a U.S. senator. Go to beautiful Maine this summer or fall for a few days or a week to campaign for her opponent. It's fun, and every vote counts in what's likely to be a close race.

Sanders also leads  Buttigieg by about 2500 votes in the realignment.  With 3% of the precincts still unreported, many of them in Polk County (Des Moines), Buttigieg now leads Sanders in delegate equivalencies by a slim margin of 26.2 to 26.1. The impeachment gamble was always a poor strategy for removing Trump from office.  It was unrealistic to expect the Republican rank and file to vote him out.  

The way to defeat Trump is to nominate Bernie Sanders.

Great that Mitt had his moment -- hallelujah and all that -- but what really would have been courageous would have been to take a stand earlier when there could have been time to influence other senators.

Barking Doggerel said what has been on my mind since viewing Romney's speech. Because his comment is in a reply, which are often missed, I re-post it here:
 
"Have we lost our minds?  It was a dull, religious speech made by a rich, privileged man with nothing at stake but the risk of a few frowns and, possibly, enduring the excruciating pain of a Trump tweet."

As a Utahn (and a Catholic Democrat), I'm happy I voted for Romney for senator.  I did so because I felt he would hold Trump in check. The real question is: have the Democrats learned a lesson? So far the evidence is that they haven't, but they should have.

1) They should never have tried to remove DT from office. He won the election according to the rules, and alleging "the Russians helped him!" doesn't change that.

2) They should have devoted more time towards promoting their own legislation, and opposing Trump / Republican legislation, on their own merits. At the very least that would have improved their own standing in comparison with DT's, especially among the red and purple states. By going through impeachment they antagonized the independent voters who would more likely buy the line that  Trump wasn't getting a break. And trump is now more likely to get those votes thanks to their antics.

3) They should have left it up to the electorate to decide whether to bounce DT after 4 years. They didn't need to "help" the electorate get the idea, and that overreach made them look patronizing and disrepectful, not of DT, but those whose job is to choose the next president. That will cost them.

Senator Romney's vote defines the partisanship of this inquiry.  Both on the vote to impeach in the House and to Remove in the Senate, different political affiliations voted yes: Democrats and an Independent in the House, Democrats, both Independents, and a Republican in the Senate.

Let's not forget to mention the courage of Jon Tester, Democrat of Montana, who also voted to convict.  Along with Dough Jones and Joe Manchin, their votes denied Trump the one thing he desperately wanted: a bipartisan rejection of the impeachment articles.  He didn't get it. Thank the lord.

Romney is my hero today.  Had he shown this kind of courage in running for president he would have won.   I'm grateful he's in the senate and has stood up to Trump.  This will fester for a long time in Trump's mind.

I now believe that it was worth the blood, sweat, tears and mighty effort (thank you House managers) to have the tape of Senator Romney saying out loud what all the rest of those profiles in cowardice surely knew to be true.  Guilty as charged.  I think the power of that denunciation will continue to build and build.
Romney’s speech has dispelled the funk I’ve been in since Trump’s election. A shining light of sanity. Thank you!

I disagree. Trump learned a valuable lesson that will resonate with the country of not the world. He can do anything and there will be no negative consequences. 

If a president can use taxpayer money, directed  by congress as critical help for an ally in a war against an enemy, to force that ally to help him in his re-election against his political rival, then he can do pretty much anything with impunity.

Thank you for this column.  However, I have to disagree with one of your statements:

"Perhaps, people of Maine, you haven’t noticed that your senator’s political independence tends to work best when the matter at hand is meaningless.."

Citizens of Maine have known for a very, very long time that Susan Collins only votes against her party when it costs her NOTHING.  

Susan Collins is no Margaret Chase Smith, who as a Republican Congresswoman in 1950, stood up against the lies of Joseph McCarthy with her "Declaration of Conscience Speech".   

Neither is she a William Cohen, who as a first term Maine Republican Congressman on the House Judiciary Committee in 1974, had the courage & backbone to vote for the impeachment of Richard Nixon.  

Maine citizens are ready for a Senator who votes with her independence & her conscience 100% of the time.

Until Senator Romney's speech, it felt like we were living in an Orwell novel.  We are, I suppose, but it was a huge relief that at least one Republican could honestly state the facts and use "reasoned judgment " to come to the obvious conclusion. No doubt he will be tortured by his GOP colleagues, but that speech may have been the greatest favor he ever did himself in the long run.

OK I admit it.  As I watched Romney saying what he had to say, especially with his focus on his family, my thoughts were with Seamus, strapped on the top of that car.  He'd have been proud.  May he rest in peace.

"Perhaps, people of Maine, you haven’t noticed that your senator’s political independence tends to work best when the matter at hand is meaningless." Oh, we've noticed. I'll be very surprised, and even more dismayed, if Susan Collins is returned to the Senate for a fifth term (she originally promised to serve for only two).

Gail, I always turn to your column with much anticipation for humor and perspective and, as always, I enjoyed today’s piece.  I have never been a supporter of Mitt Romney as I disagree with almost all of his political stances.  However, I have always known that (to paraphrase John McCain) “he’s a decent fellow citizen, whom I happen to disagree with”.  How I yearn for that in our leadership. I salute what he did yesterday and although it is true that he is a very wealthy, 72 year old man that doesn’t have to run for 5 years, I feel great personal sympathy for him.  Mitt and his family have lived their entire lives within the GOP ecosystem and in today’s Republican Party he will not only be vilified publicly (as is already happening; even by his own niece) but probably privately as well. He and his family will find themselves personally cut off from long-standing friends who are subjected to the cult of fear that Trump generates.  That is not a pretty picture.  He knew full well that he was putting himself, his wife and his children in a bad social predicament.  You have to admire his fortitude. .
Gail Collins was right about Romney, in all the things she said about him as he ran for President in  2012 against Obama.

Romney tacked right in 2012 to get the extremist vote and now he has the freedom to vote against Trump due to his support in Utah. I'm still thankful he made the vote. Every time we speak out and vote against the president, we illustrate that we are not Turkey or Russia.

Mitt Romney's speech nailed it. He synthesized Trump's corrupt acts and obstruction of congress into a wonderful, moving account of his responsibility to work for justice and uphold his oath to the Constitution.  It was moving and will be remembered through history.
In the end, it’s never wrong to do the right thing. Good lesson for everyone.
Thank you, thank you, thank you.  I knew eventually my patience would be rewarded with your nod to Seamus' car roof ride.

We all knew what the last sentence of this piece would be, right?

Still, brava, Ms. Collins, for putting things in perspective.  We need your voice.

Let's hope that those who voted for Trump will use Mitt Romney as an inspiration to vote Trump out of office.  

Unlike Mitt Romney who had the courage to speak and vote to to convict Trump in public, knowing full well that McConnell and most of his fellow Republicans will disapprove of his words and deed, people can quietly go to the polls and secretly vote the loud and obnoxious Trump out, knowing full well that Trump is far from perfect, despite his constant proclamations to the contrary.

We have become transactional. The majority of people in government don't do anything for a moral or noble reason, it is all about what you get out of the transaction. "What's in it for me?" or "I got mine!" should replace E Pluribus Unum as our national motto.

And a significant number of Americans follow suit. As long as they get a lower tax bill, or close an abortion center, of get to carry bazookas to the mall for personal protection, or get to build houses and strip malls on plots of wetlands that serve as the filter for the aquifer, or have the satisfaction of seeing the neighbors house cleaner and lawn crew deported, they'll not bother to look to deeply at the actual actions of the President.

There was always corruption, but Trump essentially just codified it. But no matter! No worries! As one commenter today said, the economy has never been better.

Mitt revealed himself to be a man of courage, integrity, and principle yesterday, qualities many of us thought had all but vanished from the Republican Senate. He was the first Senator in history to vote for the removal of a president governing his own party. His historic speech stands as a testament to what we can achieve if only we have the courage of our own convictions. Right now, Mitt is suffering an assault of ill-will by members of his own party. He deserves the gratitude of the entire nation.

On this day I think long and lovingly of my emigrant Irish grandparents - through whom I was able, almost 30 years ago, to acquire dual citizenship with the country of their birth, and thus make me able to live and work in any EU country unimpeded.  That’s my sole source of hope in these depressing times.

Yes, Gail, the people of Maine have noticed for too many years, Susan Collins' hypocritical efforts to play both sides of an issue.  She's notorious for waiting until the danger is over before sticking her neck out.  And those votes for Brett Kavanaugh and the tax "reform" package showed her true colors.  The sad thing?  She claims Margaret Chase Smith and William Cohen as her political mentors.  Where is Collins' conscience?

Not much that is good occurs in the public political arena. So when an exception arises, we should not only celebrate it, but bask in it as well.  The inspiration of a few people in the senate is going to have to be good enough to carry us through the Nov. election.  The result of that election has to be a flat out statement backed up by action that Trump is out.

Mitt Romney isn’t the only wealthy septuagenarian GOP Senator whose next election is far off. He deserves a bit of credit. Maybe he voted to convict out of personal resentment and spite, which maybe was the reason the late Sen. John McCain torpedoed Trump’s dismantling of the ACA (Obamacare). So what. There was bipartisan support for conviction in the Senate, in a manner of speaking. Build from there, and never forget that it was an old line, vicious, adamantly white supremacist Sen. Sam Ervin who, to the delight of those of us who came of age reviling him, was instrumental in bringing down Richard Nixon in the Watergate scandal.

Doug Jones is the legitimate profile in courage, even though he declines the label. His guilty votes, both of them, risked far more than Romney's one guilty vote from the perch of his safe Utah senate seat.
Jones' speech was heartfelt, meaningful, and stated a no fuss truth about knowing right from wrong.
Romny, God, tears and all, couldn't even manage a guilty vote on the second article, obstruction of Congress.
While I thank Romney for what he did, I refuse to forget all the things he hasn't done in the three years Trump has defiled the presidency and the constitution.
If you don't live in Alabama, and can't vote for Jones, there's another option. Send money to support his campaign. He's more than earned it.

The Republican Party of the Trump era will ultimately be remembered for four things: The first three are appointing right wing judges, refusing to consider any meaningful legislation on almost any important issue, and acquitting Donald Trump. The fourth is a complete abandonment of their morals and ethics due to their lust for power at any cost and their abject fear that Trump will tweet something that costs them re-election.

Good Lord, at the age of 60, I am wondering how much more polictical drama through which I must go.

A lot more, I suspect, considering how much older most of these folks are than I am.

Thank you, Gail Collins, for pointing out how little that Mitt Romney had to lose in casting his vote to impeach. Nothing, in fact. All this adulation for him that I'm reading seems over the top. Undeserved.

I never doubted Romney’s integrity. What he did was monumental because it made yesterday’s news cycle about him and shut out Trump(I don’t watch Fox). This had to infuriate Trump. I would vote for Romney over anyone of the Dem candidates except Mayor Pete or Mayor Mike. I may get a chance for that vote in four years when Mitt is 77 which seems to be the right age to run for a President.

People can hold Romney up as a "profile in courage" all they want, but I think the truth is that either his polling shows he could vote for conviction and retain his seat or that he got to the Senate, realized what a cesspool it is, and has decided being there is simply not worth it.  

In other words, there are very few people who voted whose vote can't be explained in large part by how it impacts their ability to keep their jobs.

I have long resisted calls for term limits, in part because we have term limits now - it's called "voting."  But I have unfortunately come to the conclusion that neither our system nor those who vote can be trusted.  When you hear again and again that those in Congress will admit among one another what many of us believe to be true about this President, yet will not act on their beliefs out of fear of losing an election, it is time for a change.  

When keeping your job becomes more important than doing what is right, you really have no reason to do that job.

Ultimately, it's not only Trump who has not learned a lesson, but it is us, too.

All the arguments Republicans put forward, including Collins's, are simply rhetorical cover for their votes to acquit. Lipstick on an elephant.
They know exactly what Trump did and that it has given them a stolen Supreme Court seat, tax cuts, and conservative judges for a generation. 
Any wonder why Republicans cut funding to fight election interference? It keeps their minority party in charge. The 48 Senators who voted "Guilty" represent 18 million more Americans than those who voted to acquit. Democrats have the majority of votes and are kept out of power by gerrymandering, voter suppression, and now foreign interference which Republicans embrace.
Unlike Republicans before Trump who concealed their schemes to stay in power, Trump has made it acceptable to say "get over it". Do they know we can see them? Do they know the rest of the world can see them?
Register and Vote on November 3rd to clean up voting districts, keep McConnell away from the gavel, and, yeah, let Collins and other Republicans know we can see them.
I don't remember the source but my favorite description of Susan Collins is:  "The always-overestimated Susan Collins."
Mitt Romney just showed what a president he would have made.  He is a man with a moral backbone the likes of FDR.  I applaud him and hope he runs for president again.

Think party-line Democrats "learned a lesson" from all this?  After all their efforts to expose Trump's activities regarding Russia - or now Ukraine - the American people are not compelled.  3/4 of voting America are not Democrats - and 7/8 of voting-age America aren't Democrats.  Non-Democrats are rarely impressed with the partisan activities of our party.  Even a sizable minority of Democrats (maybe 20%, including me) are not impressed with our hyper-partisan efforts.  In short, probably 90% of the opinion articles in this paper reflect the views of 10% of American adults.  One tenth - this is just a SLIVER.

What is wrong with the people of Maine? Every time I see Susan Collins speak, in that very slow, i can't say measured, voice, i am amazed that she got as far as she did.
She has to be the worst excuse for a senator I have ever seen, and that takes in a lot of excuses.
There are words to describe her, but we are not allowed to use them anymore.

Senator Wayne Morse speaking against the Tonkin Gulf Resolution on August 7, 1964. 

“I believe that history will record that we have made a great mistake in subverting and circumventing the Constitution of the United States… I believe this resolution to be a historic mistake. I believe that within the next century, future generations will look with dismay and great disappointment upon a Congress which is now about to make such a historic mistake.”

Wayne Morse was one of only two members of both chambers of Congress to oppose giving the President a free hand to go to war in Vietnam.  

Different times and different circumstances, but the rightness of this courageous senator’s thoughts ring loudly once again.

Of all of the dog-on-the-roof references over the years, Gail, this was my favorite.

Kudos to Mitt, though. His speech was exemplary. I know the long-term costs are low for him, but I was still comforted to see someone in the GOP say something sane.

Thank you Mitt! My gut told me you would do the right thing. But my gut, unlike Trump's, is not 100% perfect. The take away lesson from the wildly successful UK election of Boris Johnson is that the Democrats need to pick a moderate candidate like Buttigieg, Klobuchar, or Biden. To pick an uber-liberal like Corbyn, whom I admired for his decency, will just give Trump a 2020 landslide. The right wing press will eviserate a liberal.

The only true emotion I could see with Pence at the State of the Union came when Trump announced that Republicans are continuing to busily stack the courts.  Pence gave a long and seemingly genuine smile with that one.  Someone must have told him, at some point, what the big prize really is.  So there was the “tell,” the big confirmation for all of us.

As if we really needed it.  Still, it can be helpful to actually see it with your own eyes.

Of course Trump has learned a lesson - that he can do ANYTHING and get away with it. If we thought he was bad before this, hold on, it's going to be open season for whatever chaotic whims he has. And if anyone believes that the 2020 election won't be a problem better think again.

Senators who voted not to hear witnesses and therfore hold a thorough trial have lost sight of their oath of office.  And judging from the evidence we did see from the House, Senators who voted to acquit have lost their sense of right and wrong.

In either case, those Senators are unfit for office.  It's just that simple.

Mitt’s profile in courage would have been much more convincing had he voted guilty on both articles of impeachment. But i guess that was marginally better than Senator Collin’s vote for witnesses and then voting to acquit. Which was still only marginally better than senators Murkowski, Portman, Alexander and Rubio who criticized Trump but were unable to find a backbone to vote to convict and then laughably criticized the process as partisan. Only 270 odd days until Election Day.

To start with, Donald J. Trump did learn a lesson. He learned that next time he needs to do a better coverup. As Big Jule said in Guys and Dolls, "38 arrests, no convictions."

Mitt Romney stood up for what was right. Susan Collins and the other GOP Senators folded. It's time to consign those up for reelection to the dust bin of history come November.

I have no problem giving Sen. Romney full credit for voting guilty. It was the right thing to do. It doesn't diminish his action even if it also was a personal stick in the eye to DJT. 

The potentially wavering Democratic senators also deserve kudos for staying the course.

Actually Trump has, as Susan Collins said, “learned from this case.” He's learned that he can get away with literally anything and the Republican Party will not so much as a slap on the wrist. There was never any hope that there would be 67 votes to convict, but I had wondered if a few of the so-called moderates would vote against Trump.

Only Mitt Romney did.

All I can say is that I hope our neighboring "moderate" Senator Collins starts her well-earned retirement next January.

Mitt may have voted with his conscience today but there are thousands of people out there who were negatively affected by the Bain Capital buying of businesses, stripping the assets and selling the remains to China.  And Mitt was a major partner of Bain.  He may be a Bishop in his church, but not all of his behaviors are truly Christian.

If I were a Republican in Alabama I'd vote to reelect Doug Jones strictly on the basis of what he did yesterday.  Anyone who values their integrity to the extent that he does is someone worth keeping in Washington despite one's feelings about their views on specific issues.

Thanks, Gail.  Good piece.

Yes, Romney did the right thing on the first Article of Impeachment, though it's sad that that should engender so much hoopla.

But let's not forget that he voted not guilty on the second Article of Impeachment - obstruction of Congress.  That is at least as destructive to our system of government as the first Article, and is the greatest danger for any accountability of a rogue President.  What does Romney have to say about that?  I'd say he was trying to have it both ways with his party, detracting from his "courageous" vote on Article 1.

What Mitt Romney did today is the finest thing I have ever seen any politician do.  Under crushing pressure from Republican colleagues cowering from Trump, and a rabid president who is the modern incarnation of Joseph McCarthy, Romney spoke his conscience and defended the Constitution.  It was rousing.

Sitting Shiva for US Democracy 

US Democracy, age 231, was pronounced dead today by Chief Justice John Roberts after a long illness. 

Although suffering from birth defects and near-death episodes in the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries, the idea of American Democracy was widely admired around the world for more than 2 centuries. 

Increasingly sickly since the 1980s when it was diagnosed with Rauch's Sclerosis, Democracy withstood a series of severe setbacks in recent years. 

The immediate cause of death was The McConnell Syndrome, an obstruction of most of its passages. 

Pallbearers include Lindsey Graham, Lamar Alexander, Rand Paul, and Lisa Murkowski. Donald Trump is expected to deliver the best eulogy ever.

In lieu of flowers, we ask that you donate to your family office's tax-exempt foundation.

Susan Collins just guaranteed she will lose this Fall, you can't win by being scared. People are looking for authenticity and she had her chance, but fear of some tweets and a few million in attack ads turned her into just another self preservationist politician.

With all respect to those singing Senator Romney's praises, and the man himself, IMO we've lost sight of how courageous Doug Jones's stand is. As Gail said, he's the most endangered Dem senator out there. While Senator Romney's stand has made him a target of much vilification and maybe even a tweetstorm from the occupant of the white house, his seat is far more secure than Doug Jones's. Utah voters love Romney in a much greater percentage than Alabama voters love Doug Jones.

Ms. Susan Collins is up for re-election in November of this year.

I had always thought Maine voters were rather independent. Ms. Collins has tried to appear as if she "thinks for herself" and respects the desires of her constituents, but it appears that when it is time for her to vote, she makes up an excuse and casts her vote as Mr. McConnell would wish.

If her constituents are happy with that: a feeble excuse and then voting the party line, then she is an excellent Senator for the state of Maine and should be re-elected. 

But if the citizens of Maine are less than happy with her initial statements of "independence" from her party's line, followed by some meaningless comments and then her usual vote joining those her Republican colleagues, they have the opportunity this November to vote Ms. Collins out of office.

Are we supposed to find hope in the "courage" of Romney, Jones and Manchin -- or despair in the cravenness of Collins, Murkowski, Alexander and the dozens of other Republican senators who grovel at Trump's feet?

Romney deserves a lot of credit as the only (that means ONE) Republican (along with ONE ex-Republican, Justin Amash) to vote for the Constitution.  On the other hand, he voted to acquit on obstruction of Congress.  That charge was so obviously correct that I don't understand Romney's vote.  Is he still trying to have it both ways?  He must know that's impossible.

Mr. Romney and I probably don’t agree on a lot of the issues. However, I have to applaud his speech today.  It was nice to see one of the lemmings turn back from the edge of the cliff. 

A few things that make me hopeful for the future:
* Mark Kelly is currently the top fund raiser for all Senate candidates- even topping Mitch. 
* Amy McGrath, who will be running against Mr. McConnell, is not far behind in fundraising. 

Here’s to hoping that their momentum continues and they are sworn in as freshman Senators in 2021.

I truly believe that Senators Romney, Manchin and Jones followed their conscience by voting to convict even though doing so may have been contrary to their political interest. Sometimes people, even senators, do their duty regardless of the political calculations even though not doing so would not have changed the outcome.

"A) Susan Collins saying it’s O.K. to keep Donald Trump in office because he’s 'learned from this case.'"

Sorry to disagree Gail.  Collins was spot on. Trump has learned that he was right all along: the rule of law doesn't apply to him and his 5th Avenue remark during the 2016 campaign was a "perfect" metaphor.

I wanted to thank Gail Collins for quickly recognizing that the driver of the car with the dog on the roof ended up being the person with the most integrity in this impeachment vote. Congratulations to Senator Romney for standing tall on this issue. I can only imagine the pressure of such a vote. 

Also, congratulations to Gail Collins for seeing that such a stance needed to be immediately recognized.

Well done to both public figures. And this comes from a lifelong Democrat!

I was surprised when Collins voted to acquit Trump, because I thought that McConnell would give her permission to do so in order to boost her chances of re-election.  Seems he wouldn't let her, probably because he wanted to keep all GOP senators in support of Trump.  So much for Collins' vaunted independence.  I think that most Maine voters will understand that Collins has lost any claim she had to putting the interests of Maine and the country ahead of her pathological need to curry favor with her party leaders and Trump.  Too bad for her.

No Democratic Senator could find the gumption to convict Bill Clinton in his impeachment trial. In fact, until today no Senator had ever voted to remove a President of his/her own party.  Susan Collins is the very sad, very familiar norm through 150 years of our history. Let’s give Mitt Romney a nod of appreciation for integrity and courage,  and not entertain cynical speculation about his motives.  I feel a little bit better about being an American when such a thing is possible.

Mr Romney reminded me of why I was once proud of my country. Back then Mr Romney would most certainly been removed for the breach of honor, never mind hundreds of millions of Congressionally approved funding. There were many awful injustices when I was young, but, for the most part, there were points of honor never to be breached. And Walter Cronkite brought the same news from the same mouth into nearly every Americans ears at the same time! And, of course, news stories were spun and spewed but there was no shame in correction of an error by the proof of the truth. Anyway, I miss that sense of honor that brought dignity to our leaders.
Thanks so much for the good words, Ms. Collins.  I especially appreciated your last sentence.  Can she really mention the dog in a column that is both sad and serious?  Yep!

I grieve for the United States. If Trump is reelected to another four year term, he will do incalculable damage to the Republic and the rest of the world. That a man so manifestly unprincipled, so obviously mentally disturbed, so completely consumed by self-interest should occupy the most powerful office in the world with access to nuclear codes and the awesome might of the US military is a disaster that is simply waiting to happen. Who will restrain him? His cabinet? There are no independent members left. Congress? The Senate has submitted to his demands. The Supreme Court? The Republicans appointees have a clear majority. When Trump decides to jump off a cliff, he will take us all with him.

Just think, it wasn't that long ago that there were  presidential candidates from both parties that voters could respect even if one didn't agree with them (  Obama and McCain , Obama and Romney )  ..  but in the era of Trump ,  methinks those days are gone forever

Cannot get excited about Romney, he knew that his vote would not matter, but he got some publicity out of it. His presence in the senate has not exactly made any difference in terms of the rubber stamp the GOP has been for T. 
The mention of the dog was such a nice touch; a reminder of those distant times when politics was a more civilized activity...

A fine note of appreciation from Gail Collins, acknowledging that while Senator Mitt Romney might not be right for an assignment as Secretary of Transportation, he shows courage and decency in reminding the Nation and voters what constitutes a violation of one's oath of office.

Thank you, Sir, for bringing America back to the word 'Bipartisanship' in the face of an honorable defeat.

I deeply appreciate Gail's consistency on Romney, but he did finally listen to Jiminy Cricket and vote to convict.
 
The reminder that was not forgotten by Gail, was Seamus the family dog having to ride on the roof of the family station wagon.
Of course trump learned something. He learned he can do whatever he wants, and the Republican party will go along with it.

why is everybody (Gail Collins to boot !) getting all proud of Romney? in 5 years when he is up for reelection he will be 77-ish and ready to retire to a very well-financed pasture. if Romney was the tie-breaker vote and he went thumbs-down it would be a different story for sure but as it unfolded his vote was purely ceremonial. McCain's vote against his party blocked the destruction of the ACA which had considerably greater impact.

Wasn't Romney's health care plan (or should that be 'insurance plan') the precursor for the Democratic Party's ACA? I've heard it called the 'Romney Plan' in the past, except it was dumbed down to try to get Rebuplican support..

That the Republicans rejected it despite it originating with one of their own, someone they viewed as a loyal Republican, says more about them than it does about the plan. 

Imagine if the Republicans of yesterday had supported some kind of realistic health care plan reform. 'America' might be half-way civilized by now, and much more prosperous, with healthy,  confident citizens. 

Romney clearly doesn't belong in the Republican Party.

After today's Senate votes, I contributed to the re-election campaigns of two Democrats who face tough battles this fall: Doug Jones and Kyrsten Sinema.

I also made a modest nomination to that guy from Utah who drove to Canada with the dog on the roof of the car. Eight years ago I would have said I would never be capable of such a thing ... but things have changed.

Senator Collins failed her 'profiles in courage' moment. Rather, the best explanation of her behavior would be the simple self-serving calculation that she had more to lose by aggravating her right flank than by alienating those on her left. Those moderates and centrists have already given up on her. She just confirmed that they were justified in doing so.

I  listened to Senator Romney's statement in full today before the vote.  He has joined the ranks of John McCain, a true profile in courage.  What a rare event, and event it is, when one lives by not only his oath of office, but also his oath to his God.  And let us not overlook the guilty votes from Tester, Manchin, and the Democratic senators from Alabama and Arizona.  The two latter ones will be facing reelection in a matter of months.  What I hope most of all, however, is that both Democrats and Independents also follow their consciences this November.  Even though they may not like the final nominee we have to offer, I pray that they understand and fathom how corrupt of soul, indeed how dangerous, Mr. Trump is to our Constitutional democracy.  The real test as to courage and moral compasses is upon the American people when they cast their votes, crucial for the survival of a nation as was intended by our Fathers of the Revolution.

Mitt Romney--a politician with whom I've almost entirely disagreed over the years--today showed himself the true heir to that courageous critic of Joe McCarthy, Senator Margaret Chase Smith (R-Maine).

As for Susan Collins, who likes to invoke Margaret Chase Smith as the beacon of integrity and independence--pfft.

I live in Massachusetts and voted for Mitt Romney for governor as one of the few Republicans I ever voted for.

Today, for the first time in a long time, I was proud of my vote.

Thank you Senator Romney.

Unless the November elections removes Trump and some of his Senate enablers, you can be sure Trump and his administration will further disassemble our democratic institutions and enable further corporate take over of our environment. You can take it to the bank Trump and McConnell will be further emboldened to find ways to hold onto power past 2024 and will have little use for any remaining political norms of governance.

Even if Collins were correct, her argument suggests that “learning my lesson” is by itself adequate punishment for a crime. In fact while contrition (which Trump has not exhibited) often mitigates sentencing, judges rarely consider a defendant’s post-facto enlightenment, which would largely empty the prisons.

I think of Romney's dissenting vote as establishing a much- needed beachhead within the republican party to initiate further dialogue about necessary reforms needed within the party itself.
As is, the republican party has become a profoundly toxic and destructive entity; it is and has been on the wrong path for a few decades now, and its only going to get worse. The party badly needs a reformer and though that may not be Romney, the door needs to be wedged open and Romney has provided the wedge.

In the current craven political environment on the right, Mitt Romney looked today like some kind of strange superhuman who stopped in Mitch McConnell’s Senate to remind everybody what principles are. The guy was downright noble. Next to him, Susan Collins looked like someone who deserves to be on the Mt. Rushmore of bad faith. 
As someone who really rooted fervently against Romney becoming president, I have to say: I still greatly prefer Obama and his policies and what he represented, but, Romney, I hardly knew you. Thank you for a being a light in the darkness of the GOP.

Does anyone else think that the praise bestowed on Romney is a bit out of proportion?  It was the right way to vote, certainly, and I mean no disrespect.  But honestly, Romney had cover to do what he did because it was clear that the rest of the Republicans would protect Trump, so the one vote didn’t change anything.  Moreover, Romney had recently had a small meeting with Trump and had it laid out in advance that he would vote as he did.  Romney is a pretty predictable Republican operative, and always has been, though he gets undeserved credit for courage.

Gail, somehow you were going to remind us once again about the Romney family dog, Seamus, riding in a dog carrier on the car roof.That quirky moment will live on in lore.Importantly, Romney set an example for everyone today by insisting that he followed his conscience -that he took a solemn oath and intended to honor it.That will be remembered along with other principled Senators who opposed Joseph McCarthy and Richard Nixon.There used to be more conscience in the Senate- now there is a lot of convenience .
I have finally given up trying to follow Senator Collins' logic on impeachment.  Reluctantly, I find that the cadence of her thinking is as difficult to endure as the cadence of her speech.

"He was horrified by Donald Trump’s candidacy — vowed never to vote for him. Then there he was dining with the president-elect, lusting after a cabinet post Trump had no intention of giving him.  .  .When history looks back on Mitt Romney, this should be the moment that gets remembered. Not the uninspiring presidential race or political flip-flops."

You're wrong Ms. Collins.   Mitt Romney gives hypocrisy a bad name.  Regarding his appeals to religion and other moralistic  pleadings as well as his supposed "lost sleep" over his decision:  don't buy it.   

This decision was all about Mr. Romney's personal loathing for Donald Trump with the kind of phony window dressing that would make Martha Stewart apoplectic.

Remember how Mr. Romney described Donald Trump before his election?  He called him a "fraud" and a "con man" but after the election was just as happy to dine with the new president in hopes that he would receive a cabinet job.  To his personal pique he didn't get it.  .  .so reverted to his original hatred of the man.

Make no mistake.  The above is the reason he voted to acquit.  .  .and in a nod to Ms. Collins, yes, he has five more years to serve.  But wait.  .  .there is now talk of a recall of Mr. Romney in Utah and Mr. Trump is more popular there. So his calculus could be off by.  .  .let's say 47%!

It is interesting that some of the most eloquent and most important speeches are associated with losing causes.

To support my theory, I give you Al Gore conceding the 2000 election and Mitt Romney doing his duty to uphold his oath and obey his conscience.  Two statesmen delivering thirst quenching remarks to a nation parched and in dire need...

Gail I was nervous reading your piece, worried you wouldn't mention the dog on the roof. But you were good on your promise. And so right about the president's never learning anything; we could say the same for Susan Collins.
Thanks for making me laugh at this dark moment.

His speech was excellent. I am not a Republican but this moment might appear in a future version of "Profiles in Courage." Not because he risked anything much personally but because he was the ONLY ONE to  take a principled stand in public. He did not join the crowd, which would have was easier. He knew nobody would join him and the final outcome would not change. Maybe he hoped that if he opened the door one more good man might follow. One did, the senator from WV. Mitt Romney behaved heroically.

It took real courage to buck the peer pressure.  Senators vote along party lines for the most part, which means essentially giving up their obligation to think independently.

The framers of the Constitution didn't imagine such partisanship.  They thought that courageous men and women would often enough think for themselves, particularly when it came to difficult decisions like impeachment.

The NY Times didn't carry the Senate presentation of Alan Dershowitz, a masterful performance, but you can find it on you-tube.

Dershowitz argued that the framers of the constitution set a high bar for impeachment, and that the articles presented by Democrats, "abuse of power" and "obstruction of Congress" were too generic to be sufficient.

He argued that many presidents had been accused of "abuse of power" including Washington, Lincoln and Obama.  That impeaching on such grounds would turn the presidency into a servant of the legislature.  This would conflict with the "balance of power" the framers envisioned.

But how serious was Trump's asking the Ukraine to investigate Biden?  It is not surprising that not everybody agrees on this key issue.  Collins came down on one side, Romney the other.

But in a free society we should forego any expectation of unanimity.  People who think for themselves sometimes disagree.

I think that the people who think the economy won't continue roaring, are making a mistake about the main reason for our roaring economy.  

It's not because of Obama (although it is from something which happened while Obama was President).

It's not Trump's borrow-and-spend fiscal policy.

It's nothing to do with trade policy or tariffs (although it has had the effect of strengthening our trading-position).

It's ... well, surely you have figured it out by now.  

No?  OK.  

It's CHEAP ENERGY FROM FRACKING.

The fracking industry grew from a little niblet in 2007 to the gigantic generous giving-tree-- more than half of our total energy production-- in 2016, before Trump took office.  It is continuing to grow now.  Trump doesn't deserve credit for it, but that fact won't stop it from keeping the economy roaring. 

It's not the fracking jobs themselves (although they don't hurt).  It's that cheap energy makes EVERYTHING cheaper, faster, and easier.  Getting to work.  Buying anything that has to be transported and delivered.  Running your air conditioner or heater, and your computer.  Cooking.  Exercise.  Entertainment.  Providing medical care.  

It's not gonna stop making the economy roar, until the market catches up and overreaches, like in 1929 and like during the dot-com bubble which ended the prosperity of the 1990s.  That is likely a long time away.

They love that he is a white nationalist. And if the economy is good, they'll view it as a vindication of his racist policies. If there is an economic downturn, he'll tell them that this is all the fault of their brown-skinned neighbors, and they'll gladly believe those lies.

Three long years into this hellish presidency, Trump voters worship him like a deity. He is a known felon who, it has been proven, tried to sell out our country for his own personal gain. But none of this matters to his voters. As long as he tells them that as whites, they are the only "real" Americans, they will do literally anything for him.

The issue not addressed here is that Trump voters and Democratic voters want two different, and incompatible versions of this country. Trump voters want a regime of soft apartheid, where their rights, as whites, are paramount over others. Democratic voters want a country in which all are given equal opportunities.

There is no resolving this issue short of partitioning the country. Whites will continue to be the single largest voting bloc, and they will do anything to preserve what they believe is rightfully, and only, theirs.

People on both sides vote with their guts far more often than with their heads, and right now many guts have Trump indigestion, but one senses not enough to regurgitate.  But given the many revelations yet to come--Trump and his minions cannot help themselves; it's their nature, it's what they are--enough people may yet get to that point.
